dataModel.title: Prototype Veg Plots Database Component Description: plotObservation
dataModel.author: J. Harris

entity.entitySummary: This table stores plot information that may vary between sampling events.
entity.entityDescription: Recognizing that a plot may be resampled and that some of the environmental conditions may change between resampling events the database design has changed to accomodate this. Now all attributes that are percieved to potentially change on the order of a decade are stored in the plotObservation table whereas those attributes deemed to be regular in time/space are stored in the plot table.

attribute.attDefinition: This is an internal database identifier assigned to each unique observation.

attribute.attNotes: Foreign key into the plot table.
attribute.attDefinition: This represents the link between an observation plot location.

attribute.attNotes: Recursive foreign key which points to the previous observation of this plot.
attribute.attDefinition: This is the plot observation that was previously made at this plot location. If observations at a plot are made every year, then this key points to the observation number that corresponds to the observation made the year before.

attribute.attNotes: The prototype software will include a tool for users to propose new methods as needed.
attribute.attDefinition: Sampling method used to describe the plot. This will be a pick list with standard plot description methods, such as Daubenmire, modified Daubenmire, Zurich-Montpellier, North Carolina Vegetation Survey and TNC (I am not sure whether TNC should be listed separately or should be considered a ZM sampling approach using a different cover scale). The reference(s) corresponding to each of these methods will be stored in the citation table.

Scale used to estimate species cover. This does not follow necessarily from the sampling method in the previous field. For instance, the ZM method can use the standard Braun-Blanquet scale, the Barkman et al. cover scale, or some other modified BB scale. Similarly, the modified Daubenmire method can use the Franklin et al. or the Pfister-Arnold cover scale. The pick list will include the following categories: several frequently used standard cover scales, and a choice of "absolute cover and "non-standard cover scale.
This is the code that the author uses to identify this observation.
If the observation takes more than a single day then this is the first day in which observations were made.
If the observation takes more than a single day then this is the last day in which observations were made.
Estimated Accuracy of the observation date.

attribute.attNotes: Use pick list; 1) Very thorough 2) Average effort 3) Hurried description; some less common species may have been missed.
attribute.attDefinition: This is the effort spent making the observations as estimated by the data collector.

attribute.attNotes: Possibly the database will determine this based on the number of fields in which data are entered. If the database determines the plot to be 'ancillary' the person entering the data will be warned.
attribute.attDefinition: Type of plot (classification/ancillary/other).
Name of the institution where the original data resides.

This is the observation id number associated with the previous record for this observation. The ideas is that at times and author will need to update or replace the data for an observation other than species related data, and this would be a way to track such changes in the observation table.
This is the version number associated with this version of a plot observation.
